title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Oil Company Accountability Act" introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each individual is treated as having made a $500 payment against the tax for the 2006 taxable year. The Secretary will remit this payment to taxpayers within 30 days of enactment. Individuals with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 in the preceding taxable year are not eligible for this rebate. The Oil Company Accountability Act introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Eligibility excludes individuals whose income exceeded $120,000 in the preceding taxable year, those with a deduction under section 151 allowable to another taxpayer in 2006, estates or trusts, and nonresident alien individuals. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. The Energy Tax Rebate introduced under the Oil Company Accountability Act will take effect on the date of the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there will be a revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies. The Energy Tax Rebate introduced under the Oil Company Accountability Act will result in the revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies for their last taxable year ending in calendar year 2005. This involves increasing the value of historic LIFO layers of inventories of crude oil, natural gas, or any other petroleum product, and decreasing the cost of goods sold for that taxable year. The Energy Tax Rebate will revalue LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies for their last taxable year in 2005. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, the taxpayer's gross income will be increased by the excess amount. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to the product of $18.75 and the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the historic LIFO layer. The Energy Tax Rebate will revalue LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies for their last taxable year in 2005. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to the product of $18.75 and the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the historic LIFO layer. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined by section 29(d)(5). Any adjustment required by this section shall not be treated as a change in method of accounting. No addition to the tax shall be made under section 6655 of the Internal Revenue Code for underpayments of estimated tax. For an underpayment of an installment required to be paid for the taxable year, no addition to tax shall be made under section 6655 of the Internal Revenue Code. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil for the taxable year. An "applicable integrated oil company" must have a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil and gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 for its last taxable year ending in 2005. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one entity, and the rule for short taxable years applies. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by these companies will not be considered a tax. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by these companies will not be considered a tax if the country does not impose a generally applicable income tax, or if the amount exceeds what would be paid under the applicable income tax. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States. This is defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for large integrated oil companies. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from that country. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined for tax purposes within this subsection. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. These amendments apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section shall not apply to the extent contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
